awd_titl_txt: Infrastructure for Predicting, Understanding, and Mitigating Zoonotic Disease Outbreaks
awd_abstract_narration:
This award to the University of Florida supports a series of workshops that will catalyze collaborations around suites of data housed in natural history collections. The workshops will identify gaps in biodiversity and infectious disease data to address basic research and broader social issues pertinent to diseases that originate from other animals. An outcome of the workshops will be a strategy for framing an integrated agenda for transdisciplinary training and research. Products of the workshops will be broadly applicable for improving the community’s understanding of infectious diseases in general, achieved through the strengthening the cyberinfrastructure supporting and connecting the important data stored in natural history collections. The plan is to assemble a diverse group of participants that includes students and contributes to the preparation of the next generation of STEM researchers to sustain these conversations.

The funded series of workshops will bring together representatives from natural history collections, biodiversity informatics, taxonomy, systematics, ecology, genetics, virology, pathobiology, infectious disease, epidemiology, social science, and communications. This transdisciplinary effort will establish a dialogue and frame an integrated research agenda for understanding, mitigating, and predicting emerging zoonotic disease. A primary aim of the activity is to unveil the potential role of natural history specimens in pathogen discovery and mitigation, resulting in new approaches to gather, share, and interpret data and knowledge for deployment in preventing, predicting, and responding to diseases of zoonotic origins (future pandemics). To achieve this, the project will identify gaps in biodiversity and pathobiology data connections, develop possible solutions to close these gaps and enable a more synthetic view of biodiversity and human health, establish a plan for framing an integrated research agenda, and develop a plan for interdisciplinary training and research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project was to support interactions between biodiversity/collections scientists and disease experts to address issues related to understanding, mitigating, and preventing zoonotic pandemics, through workshops and facilitated discussions. The workshops were motivated by the COVID-19 pandemic, but the focus extended to all zoonotic diseases and the need for new perspectives and interdisciplinary collaboration. Two workshops were held, the first at the Digital Data 8 Conference in Lawrence, KS, in May, 2024, and the second at the American Society of Mammalogists (ASM) annual meeting in Boulder, CO, in June, 2024. At each conference, a set of presentations laid the foundation for guided discussions on bringing together the fields of museum collections and zoonotic disease. An artist at each conference captured the discussions via live illustrations. Archived compilations of presentations and illustrations are available online.

The workshops and their products promoted discussion among museum collections specialists, virologists, computer scientists, and educators and led to the possibility of new research, methods of disease control, and educational materials. These interactions were precisely the goal of the project. Furthermore, the use of art provided an effective means of public outreach about science and a potential novel teaching tool. Museum collections, particularly of mammals, but also of microbes, pathogens, and genetic resources, are a key component of scientific infrastructure and were considered integral to understanding the origins, evolution, and spread of zoonotic diseases. Finally, prediction, mitigation, and prevention of zoonotic diseases, such as COVID-19 and others, require all potential sources of information, and much can be learned about pathogens from museum collections. The connections among scientists promoted through the workshops supported by this grant have potential relevance for human health and society.
